job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Providence, RI
pros: Amazing chance to teach students if you like art and design.
cons: Hard if you don't like art and design.

pros: Great for learning and getting experience for students with talented advisors.
cons: The pay is low relatively speaking.

pros: Get hands on experience with power tools and millwork equipment.
cons: Students can take the shop and you for granted, and you'll be the one cleaning up after them if they don't.

review_title: Don't care about their employees/ low pay
pros: In the city. Good people who work for the College. Benefits.
cons: Low pay. Human Resources department could care less for anyone who works at the college. Tenure means nothing and you're just a number.

pros: Great environment for anyone and welcoming
cons: Pay is not enough for New England

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Providence, RI
pros: - flexible - complimentary stipend - opportunity to work with different professors
cons: - only get to choose to TA for your own department

pros: Amazing colleagues in the development office. Amazing pay. Value staff. Collaborative and supportive environment. Great leader.
cons: They are building the development program and have made significant strides towards success. With a department that is building comes growing pains. It's not anyone's fault just a matter of your perspective and how you handle those challenges. If you're not the type of person who wants to hustle hard to build a portfolio, you won't do well here. You have to be the type of person who is comfortable in a setting like that and understands that it won't be all sunshine and rainbows at times. In other words alumni aren't use to having a giving conversation. They great work the development office is doing is building that narrative so if that excites you, well then you're in the right place!

job_title: Wood Shop Monitor in Providence, RI
pros: The pay is ok, it’s towards the higher end as in student jobs
cons: Gets pretty busy towards the end of the semester

pros: Loved the people working there, not a lot of busy hours so you can do work while tending.
cons: The room gets a little dusty sometimes from the packages but minimal!

pros: I get paid to observe class and offer critique to students. There's a lot of downtime to do personal work.
cons: Not far above minimum wage

pros: Its great art school education.
cons: Does not want to expand from an art school status

job_title: Woodshop Student Employee in Providence, RI
pros: You get to see what others are working on and can learn about maintaining machines,
cons: during busy times of the semester, it's hard to find time for yourself since others need support

pros: Good for students at RISD.
cons: Balancing school work and TA can be hard

pros: The architectural department is so nice.
cons: This school needs do more on inclusive elective class.

pros: student job on campus or remote
cons: low salary . . . .

pros: nice people and nice environment
cons: low pay low pay low pay

job_title: Senior Individual Contributor in Providence, RI
pros:
Being immersed in this creative culture inspires me to strive for innovative solutions in my work and my life. I work hard because I truly care about the students and staff and I still enjoy a healthy work life balance. I can take continuing education classes for free and my managers support my professional development through training, conferences and ambitious project ideas within my work. 

I was able to make the leap from the corporate world because of the tuition remission benefit for my college-aged, kids (after 7 years on the job). This is the most significant and appreciated aspect of my compensation by far. 
Lastly, RISD has the best team mascots among any institution of higher education. (maybe don't look this up while at work)
cons: Tuition is expensive but RISD has made great strides in financial aid. RISD is very white (disclaimer: I am too) but has improved accessibility and support for BIPOC students. Like most schools in the US, RISD has much more work to do with respect to diversity, equity and inclusion for both students and staff, but I am heartened by the progress.

pros: Flexible time, great learning opportunities
cons: Haven’t seen any cons yet

review_title: Lowest Pay and the Highest Teaching Load
pros: Students do great work but are increasingly entitled and lack of understanding of the disparity in pay between faculty and administration.
cons: The teaching load is six classes per year. Each class is 5 hrs long. The starting salary is $64,000 for an Assistant Professor, whereas the national average is $79,000. There is no support or research funding for the faculty. The research office is incompetent and focused on optics rather than meaningful growth and faculty support.

review_title: Student Work at the Fleet Library
pros: I loved being able to work amongst archivists and librarians as a student. My superiors were all kind and respectful and I felt valued and supported in my time there.
cons: The only con for me was that there were no opportunities for raises since this is a student job and qualifies for work-study. It's unfortunate that I was making minimum wage for skilled labor.

review_title: A chance working with some of the best professors in the world
pros: A chance working with some of the best professors in the world
cons: Much more money if you are a graduate

pros: - Wonderful to be around professors who you vibe/work well with and gain additional experience from their course - if you like teaching, this is a good opportunity to show your supportive/encouraging side!
cons: - pay is okay. - Bit of a time commitment (looking at a full day/half day's worth of time).

pros: Flexible, compatible with student schedule
cons: Minimum wage is not living wage

pros: Flexible work hours to be able to work while attending classes. Positive work environment and good work-life balance.
cons: Pay is on the lower end.

job_title: Annual Fund Officer in Providence, RI
pros: Amazing people. Upward mobility. Mission and human centered.
cons: Departments can be siloed at times.

review_title: Pairs well with academic life as a student at RISD
pros: Excellent co-workers, campus resources, and professional development
cons: Benefits and pay could be better. Management varies but is competent for the most part.

job_title: Laser Cutter Monitor in Providence, RI
pros: Low key Good working environment Able to do other work when there are no appointments
cons: I can't think of any cons

pros: simple work, good work&life balance, had a lot of time to study
cons: needed some time to get used to different kinds of gear (and how to handle them) in the beginning.

pros: Get paid while going to school.
cons: The wage per hour for student worker is a little bit low.

pros: Lovely coworkers and supportive environment
cons: Equipment resources were not shared among other departments

review_title: Good work environment, little opportunity for job growth
pros: Great co-workers and students. Beautiful campus.
cons: There are very few opportunities for job growth. Most folks have to leave RISD, work somewhere else, and then reapply to ever move up.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Providence, RI
pros: Learning with students to explore different studio art techniques
cons: Sometimes might be boring since the professor doesn't need any help during class

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Providence, RI
pros: pay equal to worked hours
cons: underpaid adds up to around $12

pros: The students are excellent and hard working.
cons: Much of the teaching goes unappreciated by Deans or Division Leaders.

pros: the students and the museum
cons: low salary to experience ratio

pros: Amazing place to work at
cons: Can be challenging to work at

pros: Good benefits for families like tuition reimbursement. I'm happy this benefit is now extended to hourly employees (not helpful if you don't have children).
cons: Stagnant administration, toxic culture that values hierarchy and policing, too many "directors" AND it's still difficult to get promoted. A good job if your local considering the options in Rhode Island but not worth moving to Providence to work at RISD unless you your hired as full time faculty.

job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Providence, RI
pros: Relative ease working as a student, however, your experience depends entirely on which professor you are working for
cons: Should not be your main source of income as hours are inherently limited

pros: Flexible and Fun. You can learn a lot from students.
cons: Sometimes you have to work late.

pros: Work is great, I like work in here
cons: a lot of work to do, help student

job_title: Director, International Student Services in Providence, RI
pros: The students are amazing and it's great working with creative people. My colleagues are also great.
cons: The leadership and pay are not good.

review_title: Good for WorkStudy / Consistent Classroom Experience, Low Rates
pros: Compared to other teaching assistant jobs, the amount of hours is very customizeable and pretty low per class (perfect for a workstudy job). You get to meet a lot of interesting new teaching artists as well! Supervisors generally very understanding of your limits
cons: Low pay! Can also line up rather unfortunately with class or break schedules so be careful when signing up.

pros: Love working with professors to help run the class
cons: Hard to find time in schedule because of intense workload

job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Providence, RI
pros: Enjoyed working in a class I previously enjoyed.
cons: It was COVID peak year

pros: Perfect Perfect Perfect Perfect Perfect
cons: None None None None None

review_title: Pay is great but hours are horrible
job_title: Laser Cutter Monitor in Providence, RI
pros: Job is simple and easy to manage. You mostly work with students which is great. Since youre employed by the school the hours are very flexible too.
cons: The amount of students that work the same job is you is a lot so its hard to get a good amount of hours to be able to make a decent amount.

pros: Interdisciplinary, many opportunities for collaborations
cons: Overworking. RISD has a poor work life balance

review_title: High Tuition, less competitive gratuitous high tech
pros: Facilities and older faculty. Technicians and location.
cons: High tuition, lack of socioeconomic diversity, digital media eliminating hand skills and thinking.

pros: Easy amount of work on-top of a student work load. Everyone is always wonderful to work with. Nice workplace. Great equipment.
cons: Not all students want to follow rules. Shops left messy all of the time. The pay could be a whole bunch higher. They need to work on the amount of sawdust left everywhere.

review_title: Great atmosphere and good work environment.
job_title: Gallery Monitor in New York, NY
pros: Great for current students to find a job. easy to fit into the school schedule.
cons: sometimes very few people would show up during the day, but that is due to the pandemic.

review_title: Access to good machinery, Poor organization, Terrible pay
pros: I work in the Industrial design tech lab. I get access to a lot of fantastic machinery that I would not otherwise be able to use (because of the pandemic.) That's really why I took the job. My boss is friendly and easy to work with.
cons: I am paid less than minimum wage (is that even legal?). Our workflow is a total fustercluck, though that may become a moot point once quarantine protocols end.

pros: Good place to work. Good benifits.
cons: Hard to move up. They hire from outside the school.

review_title: Teaching Assistant position for illustration studio
pros:
- Fun reviewing basics of course 
- Great to work with a professor that you connected with
- Good to connect to students of a lower year.
cons: - Minimum wage is lower in RI compared to other US states.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in North Attleboro, MA
pros:
Health Insurance
Retirement
Working with diverse art students
cons:
Lack of work/life balance
Poor management and budgeting
Lack of necessary, up to date technology
Poor institutional outlook
Institutional racism and sexism pervasive

review_title: RISD is an amazing place to work - except in administration. Human Resources & managers were woefully inadequate.
job_title: Assistant Director of Major Gifts in Providence, RI
pros:
Campus is alive with talented, gifted students & it's really something to watch them grow into true artists from their freshmen year. RISD is also a design school so there are a lot of opportunities for mixed media. The alumni list is stellar. I had the enviable job of visiting with alumni & parents across the country during RISD's largest campaign in its history - $85,000,000.
There was never a dull moment with so many diverse people to meet and learn about.
cons: Unfortunately, RISD needs to get as good at administrative creativity as it is at art & design Admin is stuffy & not enough leadership know-how. I, along with a few other employees were pretty much being mentally abused by a senior administrator we reported to - the usual channels of reporting problems was very weak - the Asst VP and Vp of advancement ignored reports & Human Resources were absolutely useless and, in the end, incompetent to the point of absurdity. Hours are grueling but that's the nature of the business whether an artist or road warrior. A lot of travel & too much of a numbers game - there should be some balance.

review_title: Great Connections, Hard to fit into schedule
job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Providence, RI
pros: Great people to work with, and lots of networking opportunities. Professors know a lot of people within their respective fields.
cons: Hard to find time to work while concurrently taking course load

review_title: Very healthy environment to work in
pros: Incredible staff, very hands-on and care about your growth.
cons: The only downside is organization throughout the department.

pros: Very talented people, great students, leadership in my department is good, but can vary quite a bit by department. excellent facilities,
cons: Topheavy administration, communication can sometimes be unclear between administration and faculty.

review_title: It's a good place to TA
pros: Work with students, Create relationships, gain teaching assistance
cons: low pay, hard work, often can be hard.

pros: it's good to work with a team
cons: it's labor tiring and time pressing

pros: Housing, meal plan provided, community support with other RA's
cons: Work, life, school balance, situational challenges

pros: Excellent student talent and great community

pros: Getting to interact with students
cons: minimum wage, more pay would be desirable.

pros: Excellent Colleagues, inclusive department, great staff
cons: Extra work without feeling appreciated by the students

pros: flexible hours, good for experience
cons: low pay, otherwise a good job

review_title: Great students, supportive environment for adjuncts
pros: Union for part-time instructors is very active. Good pay for adjuncts.
cons: Everything is fine. No problems so far.

pros: incredibly creative and invigorating environment
cons: the campus can be siloed sometimes, but even that is improving!

job_title: Senior Membership Associate in Providence, RI
pros: I am able to be creative
cons: I am not allowed to work from home

review_title: Good place to be a student employee if you aren't too busy.
pros:
I worked as a teaching assistant and as a resident advisor at RISD. 

TA Pros:
-Opportunity to work with a teacher you respect
-Manageable hours
-Fun to interact with freshmen

RA Pros:
-Great supervisors who care about your personal development
-Good compensation (free room and reduced price meal plan)
-Kind students who are overall easy to work with
-Great co-workers who are supportive of one another
cons:
TA Cons:
-Poor pay for the time invested, since you cannot work on schoolwork at the same time. Not a good work-study job for someone who needs to work multiple jobs and stay on top of their schoolwork.
-Schedule is inflexible.

RA Cons:
-Very time-intensive. Weekly 3 hour staff meetings, two monthly events to organize, and obligation to make a new bulletin board each month. 
-Experience varies a lot based on your residents and area.

pros: Lots of nice co-workers, fairly tolerant environment for minorities, gender-queer, artists, freaks in general. Dress code usually casual. Pay is decent, benefits quite good.
cons: Disorganization. Systems that are tied in knots. Faculty that make busy-work. Higher-level admins sometimes have an attitude problem, think they are special, and are paid too much to do sometimes very little. This leaves lower-level admins feeling under-valued.  As with many places, those at low end of totem pole must sometimes show leadership and initiative beyond their pay grade.  Can be very clique-ish.

job_title: Work Study Tour Guide in Providence, RI
pros: I'm a student at RISD but I've also done some work study programs. They treat us well, paying like $12.30 an hour to give tours of the school. RISD is very generous with what they pay us and many of their other employees.
cons: There are some minor feuds between major departments and it somehow makes some of the other part time and some full time workers in unions believe that they are underpaid when they are really making much more than anyone else would pay them for the same work.

job_title: Teaching Assistant, Architecture Department in Providence, RI
pros: Provides a great opportunity to get experience with teaching and assisting fellow students with classes.  Because you TA for a class you've already taken, you basically get to take it again and thus get to learn the material twice.  And you make some money while doing it!
cons: Can be tough to work time for TA duties into an already busy class schedule.  It tends to be particularly stressful around exam time when you have your own exams on top of doing reviews and answering questions for the students in your TA class.

review_title: Good school, but give some of that tuition fee to the staff trying to make it good
job_title: Continuing Executive Director Faculty in Providence, RI
pros:
-Great school
-Great facilities
-Friendly folks who work there
-Genuine effort to stay current, thoughtful, and smart WRT design trends
cons:
-Low pay for teachers, adjuncts, contractors when I was there
-As with most schools, most people are contractors-- getting an actual full-time gig is barely a thing anymore. They don't seem to invest in their teachers, yet the tuition seems to get higher. 
-Getting a parking pass was weirdly difficult when I was there, hope that has changed. Parking in Providence is fraught as it is.

review_title: Work hard, work fast, amazing people
pros: It's a super creative environment. The staff is very focused on making it a great place for the students. People are passionate about their work. Overall, it is a very supportive community. My manager cared a lot about me and my growth as a person and professional. Summers are low-key, which is good because work during the school year is very intense.
cons: Compensation was on the low side (especially compared to neighboring Brown) and I worked more hours than I would have liked.

pros: A nice campus environment with talented students and faculty.  Being able to take free classes is super.
cons: The administration has been toxic and slow.  Some of the policies are way too corporate for a higher education environment and very unfriendly to its employees.

review_title: A good experience as adjunct teaching goes.
pros: Compensation c. $5000 per course is decent compared to adjunct contracts at many other schools.  Adjuncts are eligible for conference travel and teaching enrichment grants.  Because a large number of adjuncts teach at RISD, staff (admin, library, etc) are accustomed to dealing with the needs of adjuncts and do so well.   A strong union protects the interests of adjunct faculty.
cons: Poor office space resources for adjunct faculty.  Adjuncting is a permanent institution here (i.e. low rate of intake of adjuncts into permanent faculty).

pros: There's a good sense of community amongst the workers who don't hesitate to help you out.  Managers are also friendly, giving critiques as to what to do when I do something wrong.  One of the best things about the Fleet Library is that you can come across books that you've never seen before and find many things to catch your interest.
cons: Sometimes difficult to find a shift to make enough money, though one could say the same for any job.  Even more difficult when you're a student.

pros: Working for RISD was a great experience. The staff was very friendly and working there was very fun and a great experience as a student at the time.
cons: Often times there were no jobs or work given to me at the office so I would have nothing to do but refresh the email page over and over for an entire day.

pros: The department works hard to support students and have a relationship with the student community. You can take advantage the resources they are willing to provide you with. The people are caring and supportive.
cons: The department is constantly getting restructured and is disorganized. You have to be self-motivated and initiate workload or projects.

job_title: Textile Technicians Assistant in Providence, RI
pros: I Learned a significant skill set as a technician's assistant that I feel would help any person seeking to be a studio assistant or intern.
cons: I was paid minimum wage while I was there and the work was definitely physically intensive, involving a lot of scrubbing and elbow grease.

pros: paid to do homework. you basically sit and do everything you would anyway, but get paid.  Also you meet a lot of new people that you wouldnt normally meet.
cons: boring. if you dont have any work to do it kinda sucks too.  But if you dont mind being in the shops or computer labs then its a pretty good deal.

job_title: Graduate Student Assistant Advisor in Providence, RI
pros: Great working environment and amazing co-workers. Working with students was challenging while able to boost your capability. Workload can be huge and deadlines can be moved ahead. But after worked in RISD, you are generally capable to handle any work environment in the design industry.
cons: Time management is horrible sometime.

pros:
Could make my own schedule (to an extent)
Variety of tasks to complete
Practice interfacing with customers (parents and students)
cons:
Poor wages
Inconvenient time card system - if you miss the submission day, you have to wait a whole month for your pay

pros:
Allowed me to use the facilities more often.
Increased my knowledge of the machines and got me more interested.
Got to help people on their projects.
cons: Constantly need to pay attention to make sure everyone is safe.

review_title: Lacking the leadership needed for change
pros: Great environment and people.  Beautiful location and well-maintained campus.
cons: Cannot make decisions.  Has a crippling effect on progress.

review_title: RISD is coasting on its reputation
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Providence, RI
pros: the students are incredible and inspiring. some faculty are brilliant and generous
cons: the disorganization is profound. getting anything done is tribal and based on personal connection. the wheel is constantly reinvented

pros: The school and offices have a great atmosphere, but the overall work experience varies drastically between departments and teams.
cons: Low pay, lacking benefits, constant fear among employees of paycuts and department layoffs.

job_title: Precollege Resident Advisor in Providence, RI
pros: Commitment to diversity, cares about student wellbeing, staff and coworkers are largely polite and friendly.
cons: Lots of hills to walk up and down. Different departments of RISD are not very connected at all.

pros: Students at RISD are some of the most dedicated and talented around. Teaching them was personally rewarding.
cons: I did not experience any negatives in my short contract.

pros:
-amazing , fun people 
-manageable task 
-flexible schedule
cons: None to speak of. Just can get repetitive or lots of down time where nothing happens.

pros: the hours were great, pay scale is satisfactory
cons: some manager dont understand or do not care for the students homework to workstudy balance. not enough jobs

review_title: Experience of work study in RISD
pros: Good money, do work during shifts.
cons: Pays little, sometime have bad experience at work with students

pros: Very family friendly.  Great work/life balance.  You feel like you're part of a community.
cons: Sometimes the money isn't well-spent.

pros: You won't find a more inclusive and diverse work setting
cons: Cramped backroom equipment room, and eerie underground storage space.

pros: Community, Integrity, friendship, accountability, organization
cons: respect, scheduling, wages and phones

pros: access to studios, learn a lot about machines.
cons: need to be trained more to be truly helpful.

pros: Location, benefits, meal plan, no living expenses
cons: I really do love this place

pros: flexible hours and straightforward expectations
cons: can be late working hours but that is the only negative

pros: Friendly, Open-minded, Inspiring, Networking, Knowledge
cons: Long hours, unhealthy labor habits
